entry.content:
I'm a digital editor and investigative reporter with a decade of experience in audio, print and digital journalism. 

I'm currently a digital editor at WFYI, Indianapolis' public media station. I'm also the co-host of Sick, a podcast about what goes wrong in the places meant to keep us healthy. And I report for Side Effects Public Media, a journalism collaborative based at WFYI that focuses on public health challenges and inequities in the Midwest. 

I previously worked as a reporter, digital editor and social media manager at The Herald-Times newspaper in Bloomington, Indiana. 

I was part of the team of Side Effects Public Media reporters named Indiana's Journalists of the Year in 2019 by the Indiana Professional Chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists. My work has also been recognized by the Public Media Journalists Association, Indiana Associated Press Broadcasters Association, Hoosier State Press Association and Indiana Associated Press Media Editors. 

I'm a 2012 graduate of Towson University, where I met my husband, Kyle. We live in Bloomington, Indiana, with our cat, Rust. 

Find me on Facebook and Twitter.

Work Experience

Digital editor, WFYI/Side Effects Public Media (May 2018-present)

  • Edit the work of WFYI's health and education reporting teams and develop multi-platform content to accompany digital stories. 

  • Reported, produced and co-hosted Sick, a serial investigative podcast about health inequities.
  • Produced enterprise radio and digital stories on health care topics including the COVID-19 pandemic, maternal health and racial health care disparities in the Midwest.
  • As a multimedia reporter/editor from 2018-2019, I maintained social media, a weekly email newsletter and website for Side Effects Public Media, a health journalism reporting collaborative led by Indianapolis public media station WFYI. Edited other reporters’ content to present online and in social media posts.

The Herald-Times (August 2012-May 2018)

  • Digital projects and social media editor, 2016-2018
    Created video and audio multimedia packages to accompany personal reporting and the work of other reporters. Built interactive and in-depth web presence of content on HeraldTimesOnline.com. Managed and increased social media presence on platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Snapchat. Developed and managed a commenting system. Developed analytics reports of website performance using Google Analytics.
  • News reporter, 2014-2016
    Maintained health and social services beat, writing breaking news and features as well as daily stories about medicine, scientific studies and business news related to the local hospital, nonprofits and health care providers. Also served as a general assignment reporter.
  • Freelance writer, 2012-2014

Additional skills: Working with content management systems, Adobe Audition, social media, AP and NPR styles

Honors and awards: Sick (first place, Society of Professional Journalists Indiana, 2022; Best Podcast, Public Media Journalists Association, 2020; Regional Edward R. Murrow Award, Large Market Radio Podcast, 2020), Part of Side Effects reporting team named Indiana’s Journalists of the Year (Society of Professional Journalists Indiana, 2019); First place, enterprise story (Indiana Associated Press Broadcasters Association, 2019), second place, feature story (Indiana Associated Press Broadcasters Association, 2019); First place, best video (Indiana Associated Press Media Editors, 2017); First place, breaking news coverage under deadline pressure (Hoosier State Press Association, 2015, 2017); First place, best short feature (HSPA, 2016); third place, best investigative reporting (Indiana Associated Press Media Editors, 2017)

Education

Towson University, 2012
Bachelor of Science in Mass Communication with concentrations in journalism and new media and public relations

I spent four years working at The Towerlight, Towson's independent student newspaper, serving as editor-in-chief, senior editor, and arts and life editor. I also interned at the Baltimore City Paper, an alt-weekly newspaper.

entry.content:
Audio

Sick is a serial investigative podcast about what goes wrong in the places meant to keep us healthy. The second season, released in fall 2021, investigated prisons – places that have to keep people healthy, but are built to punish them. The first season, released in fall 2019, was an investigation into fertility medicine and an Indiana doctor who used his own sperm to secretly impregnate his patients in the 1970s and 1980s. The podcast earned a regional Edward R. Murrow award, first place in its division from the Public Media Journalists Association, and first place in the podcast category from the Indiana chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists. Listen to all the episodes here or wherever you get podcasts. 

Universities Rethink Building Names In The Wake Of Racial Justice Protests 
NPR, October 2020

Many U.S. colleges have lecture halls named after scientists remembered for their achievements. But in some cases, those same scientists promoted racial theories or practices that are now rejected. And increasingly, their names are being stripped from campus buildings. 

Indiana Doesn't Require Nursing Homes To Publicly Report COVID-19 Data
All Things Considered, June 2020

In many states, long-term care facilities account for almost half of total COVID-19 deaths. In Indiana, these facilities are not required to publicly report cases and deaths from COVID-19.

Health Advocates Say Some COVID-19 Testing Lacks Cultural Sensitivity 
Side Effects Public Media, September 2020

Health officials say testing is crucial to limiting the spread of COVID-19. But some health advocates say culturally sensitive care is just as important, and that’s been lacking in communities hit hardest by the virus.

Group Home Residents With Disabilities Live With Precautions To Keep COVID-19 At Bay 
Side Effects Public Media, July 2020

Nursing homes have received a lot of attention during the COVID-19 pandemic. But there are other places where many people live in close quarters, increasing their risk of contracting the virus. That includes group homes for people with intellectual and developmental disabilities.

See additional reporting from Side Effects Public Media and WFYI

 

Print

I spent nearly four years as a reporter and digital projects and social media manager for The Herald-Times newspaper in Bloomington, Indiana. I covered health and social services in Monroe County, reporting on the local hospital’s decision to relocate, rising hepatitis C rates and the settling of a white nationalist group in a nearby county. Most of my work from that time is behind the newspaper's paywall. Contact me for clips.
